learningObjectScript.subtitle: What is DNA?

node.statement:
DNA contains the instructions for most of an organism's characteristics. It is the hereditary material of all living things.

DNA is short for deoxyribonucleic acid.

It is so small that its structure cannot be seen even by powerful microscopes.

So how did scientists discover how DNA is built and how it works?

In the 1800s, biologists studying stained plant cells under a microscope observed rods in the nucleus of each cell. This was the discovery of chromosomes.

In the following decades, scientists were able to find a substance they called 'nucleic acid', which can exist in the form of chromosomes. This substance is what we now call DNA.

Next, scientists wanted to know what components or parts make up DNA. Chemical analysis had revealed that it consisted of only five elements &endash; oxygen, carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen and phosphorus.

But since it was impossible to see DNA, its structure was still a mystery. How were these chemical elements arranged?

By 1929, it was discovered that DNA could be broken down into six components:
• deoxyribose (sugar)
• phosphate
• four types of chemicals called bases: thymine, adenine, cytosine and guanine.

Trying to work out how these components fit together to form the structure of DNA was like solving a very difficult 3-D jigsaw puzzle.

Then a breakthrough came in the early 1950s. Using a process called X-ray crystallography, it was deduced that DNA had the shape of a double helix &endash; a sort of spiral ladder.

The remaining piece in the puzzle was to figure out how the six components were assembled within the structure of a double helix.

node.question:
Your task is to try to find the structure of DNA.

Let's start with the spiral chain making up the 'backbone' of DNA.

See if you can assemble the backbone of this small section of DNA by moving DNA components into position. Start at the bottom and work your way up.

Here are some hints:
• Only two of the components are needed to build this backbone.
• They are arranged in a simple repeating pattern.

node.statement:
Scientists also discovered that the sugar&endash;phosphate backbone of the double helix is connected by 'rungs' known as base pairs.

To find the components that make up the base pairs, we're going to untwist the helix so that it is easier to build.

node.question:

Your task is to construct the base pairs of the DNA by moving the correct bases into position.

Hint: only certain bases will pair up.

node.statement1:
Congratulations, you've found how the four bases pair up to form base pairs. Each rung between the sugar&endash;phosphate backbones is made from a pair of bases held together by hydrogen bonds.

The particular shapes of the bases allow the hydrogen bonds to form, increasing the attraction between adenine and thymine, and cytosine and guanine.

node.statement: A unit formed by a phosphate, a sugar and its connected base is called a nucleotide.

learningObjectScript.node:

node.statement:
Well done!

This section of DNA shows only ten base pairs. To give you an idea of the complexity of DNA, a gene can have hundreds of base pairs.

The complexity doesn't stop there. For example, humans normally have 46 chromosomes, and each chromosome carries a different number of genes.

In humans, one chromosome carries approximately 800 genes, whereas another carries approximately 2500 genes.
